barker_notes.barker_summary: Austin to James Hope, December 5, 1831. Conditions on which English immigrants will be received.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 721-722

*div1 type="summary"* *p*Austin to James Hope, December 5, 1831. Conditions on which English immigrants will be received.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*Mr. *person_mentioned*James Hope*/person_mentioned*,*/p*
*p*You inform me that you are going to *location_mentioned*England*/location_mentioned*, your *location_mentioned*native country*/location_mentioned*, on a visit, and expect that many enquiries will be made by your *person_mentioned*friends */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*relations */person_mentioned*relative to *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, and as to the encouragement that is given by this government to *person_mentioned*emigrants */person_mentioned*and in order that you may be enabled to answer them correctly you wish me to give you a memorandum on the subject—*/p*
*p*In complyance with this request I herewith hand you a *location_mentioned*pamphlet*/location_mentioned* which contains translations of the colonization laws now in force— you will find the national law on the 40th and 41st pages numbered 20, and the law of the *location_mentioned*State of coahuila and Texas*/location_mentioned* on pages 42, to 48—it is numbered 21, and commences at the bottom of page 41.— The State law is the one which prescribes the quantity of *location_mentioned*land */location_mentioned*each *person_mentioned*settler */person_mentioned*is to get and the mode of issuing the titles, The instructions to the *person_mentioned*commissioners */person_mentioned*on pages 55. 56. 57. and 58. also clearly explain the mode of issuing the titles etc—*/p*
*p*It will be seen by examining the state law above mentioned that a *location_mentioned*league of land*/location_mentioned* and a "*location_mentioned*Labor*/location_mentioned*" can be granted to each *person_mentioned*family*/person_mentioned*, and the quarter of that quantity to single men— A *location_mentioned*Mexican league*/location_mentioned* is equal to *location_mentioned*four thousand four hundred and twenty eight acres*/location_mentioned* english measure— A *location_mentioned*Labor */location_mentioned*is equal to *location_mentioned*177 acres*/location_mentioned*— The whole cost of a league of land including surveying, office fees and what has to be paid to the Government under the 22d article of the state law, will not exceed about four cents pr acre, and a considerable portion of this is payable in instalments—*/p*
*p*By a new contract which I have lately made with the *person_mentioned*Government */person_mentioned*in which I have taken *person_mentioned*Mr S. M. Williams*/person_mentioned* in as a *person_mentioned*partner*/person_mentioned*, We are authorised to introduce *person_mentioned*eight hundred European families*/person_mentioned*, and settle them on the *location_mentioned*vacant land*/location_mentioned* within the limits of and adjoin- ing my other *location_mentioned*colonies */location_mentioned*which are completed, The new *person_mentioned*emigrants*/person_mentioned* therefore who now come, will not have to settle in a *location_mentioned*wilderness*/location_mentioned*, destitute of supplies as the first *person_mentioned*emigrants */person_mentioned*did, but on the contrary, they come to a *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*abounding in provisions, and in all that is necessary to make them comfortable By the existing laws of the Mexican Govt. *person_mentioned*Europeans */person_mentioned*are prefered to *person_mentioned*North Americans*/person_mentioned*, and no people would be better received than the subjects of*location_mentioned* Great Britain*/location_mentioned*, for no *location_mentioned*nation */location_mentioned*is on more friendly terms with the *person_mentioned*Mexican Government*/person_mentioned*—*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*English farmers*/person_mentioned*, and *person_mentioned*capitalists */person_mentioned*would greatly benefit themselves by a removal to *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*— The industrious and economical habits of the former, would advance their fortunes rapidly by agriculture, and the capital of the latter invested in *location_mentioned*Manufactories*/location_mentioned*, Agriculture, or commerce would yield them an immense interest— There certainly never was such an opening on earth for *person_mentioned*european emigrants*/person_mentioned*, as is now presented in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, for it will be remembered that they are not compelled to settle in*location_mentioned* Austin's colony*/location_mentioned* unless they chuse to do so, but can settle in *location_mentioned*other parts of Texas*/location_mentioned*—it will also be rememberd that no money is required of the *person_mentioned*settler*/person_mentioned*, untill he has actually recd, his title from the *person_mentioned*commissioner */person_mentioned*of the Govt, duly appointed for that purpose—no one can get a title without an actual removal of his *person_mentioned*family*/person_mentioned* to the *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*. By the constitution and laws of this nation slavery is forever prohibited within the*location_mentioned* mexican territory*/location_mentioned*, *person_mentioned*emigrants */person_mentioned*from *location_mentioned*England */location_mentioned*would therefore do well to bring a number of *person_mentioned*laborers */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*white servants*/person_mentioned*, bound under written contracts specifying their wages and the term for which they had engaged—such contracts will be binding and enforced in this *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*. It would be a good plan to bring out a number of *person_mentioned*Dutch*/person_mentioned*, *person_mentioned*Belgian */person_mentioned*or *person_mentioned*German*/person_mentioned* *person_mentioned*families */person_mentioned*as *person_mentioned*laborers*/person_mentioned*. It is thought by some that they would be much more easily managed and more profitable, than either *person_mentioned*english*/person_mentioned*, *person_mentioned*irish*/person_mentioned*, or *person_mentioned*scotch*/person_mentioned* *person_mentioned*laborers*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p**person_mentioned*Emigrants */person_mentioned*will be required to produce evidence of their good moral character, respectable standing, and industrious and sober habits, from the judicial or *person_mentioned*civil authority*/person_mentioned* of the *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*they remove from, which must be properly authenticated to avoid frauds and impositions, without this indispensable requisite, land will not be granted to them as *person_mentioned*settlers*/person_mentioned*—.*/p*
*p*On their arrival in this *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*, those who wish to settle under the [last] contract of *person_mentioned*Austin */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*Williams*/person_mentioned*, must apply to one of those persons in this place, and report himself with a list of his *person_mentioned*family*/person_mentioned* and present his documents of recommendation, and also his passport from the *person_mentioned*mexican consul*/person_mentioned* of the *location_mentioned*port */location_mentioned*where he saild from*/p*
*p*[Stephen F. Austin.]*/p*
*p**location_mentioned*San Felipe de Austin*/location_mentioned* *date_mentioned n="12-05-1831">5th December 1831*/date_mentioned**/p*
*/div1*
